Yes, there are many real-life examples of the impact of using OER in improving access to education. Here are some of them:

1. Rwanda: In 2017, Rwanda committed to providing free access to OER in schools. The government partnered with the Open Learning Exchange (OLE) to develop and distribute OER content across the country. This initiative helped to address the cost barrier and improve access to education, especially in underserved regions.

2. India: In 2016, the Indian government launched the National Repository of Open Educational Resources (NROER) to provide digital learning resources and OER materials to learners across the country. This initiative helped to improve access to education in remote areas where traditional schools may not exist.

3. Southern Africa: In 2015, the Southern African Development Community (SADC) launched the SADC OER project, which aimed to develop and distribute OER materials to promote collaboration and improve access to education in the region. The initiative helped to address issues such as cost, quality, and relevance of educational materials.

4. United States: Community colleges in the United States have been using OER to reduce the cost of education for students. For example, the State University of New York's Open SUNY Textbooks project promotes the use of OER materials in place of costly textbooks. This initiative has helped to improve access to education for low-income students who may struggle to pay for textbooks.

In conclusion, these real-life examples highlight the positive impact of OER in improving access to education. By using OER, institutions can reduce educational inequalities and provide high-quality education to learners who may not have otherwise had access to it.
